Carbon disulfide is used for cellulose sponge production at the Nylonge Elyria Facility.  Storing and handling large quantities of carbon disulfide can create hazardous situations.  The Nylonge Facility takes safety obligations in storing and using carbon disulfide.  The Nylonge Elyria Facility carbon disulfide handling process is subject to the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Risk Management Program and Plan (40 CFR Part 68 requirements).  Since the facility is located in the State of Ohio, the implementation of the RMP program has been delegated to the Ohio Environmental Protection Agency (Ohio EPA) (OAC 3745-104 requirements).  The Program requires a summary in the Risk Management Plan (RMP) of policies and procedures followed to safely operate the facility, including a description of the possible consequences in case of an accident and the actions, which will be taken by the facility in an event of an emergency.  The following information is specifically required in the RMP Executive Summary: 
?    Accidental release prevention and emergency response policies.
?    General facility and regulated substances information.
?    Offsite consequence analysis results.
?    Summary of the accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps.
?    Five-year accident history summary.
?    Emergency response program summary.
?    Planned changes to improve safety.
The above information for the Nylonge Elyria Facility is provided below.
Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies
The Nylonge accidental release prevention policy involves a unified approach that integrates the use of proven technology, trains staff in operation and maintenance practices, and uses tested and proven management system practices.  All applicable requirements of the State of Ohio and EPA?s Prevention Program are adhered to, including key elements such as training, systems management, and emergency response procedures.
The Nylonge emergency response policy involves t

he preparation of emergency response plans for hazardous materials, which are tailored to each facility and to the emergency response services available in the community, and is in compliance with the USEPA and State of Ohio EPA Program Emergency Response Program Requirements.  The Nylonge Elyria Facility is a first responder.  It has trained employees to respond to carbon disulfide accidental releases.  It has developed and prepared an emergency action plan (standard 1400-3) for the purpose of protecting public health and the environment.  The Nylonge Elyria Facility has an excellent record in preventing accidents from occurring.
General Facility and Regulated Substance Information
The Nylonge Elyria Facility is located in Lorain County, at 1301 Lowell Street, approximately 40 miles west of Cleveland, Ohio.  Major roadways near the facility include Interstate 90, as well as State Routes 57 and 113.  The facility uses carbon disulfide for production of cellulose sponges.  The maximum quantity of carbon disulfide stored at any given time is either contained within one railcar, two fixed storage tanks, or multiple day tanks throughout the facility.
Railcars transfer carbon disulfide (CS2) to the bulk storage area once every 10 weeks. The railcar volume is 20,000 gallons to 20,500 gallons; however, the volume of CS2, which is stored in the railcar, varies between 16,670 gallons and 17,130 gallons.  Two CS2 storage tanks are located in the bulk storage area.  Each tank is equipped with level switches, and level transmitters that send data to the control room.  CS2 is then transferred from the storage tank to a metering tank.  There are a total of three similar systems, each consisting of a metering tank, dissolving water tank, steeping caustic tank and a reactor.
Containment is provided around the railcar to reduce the vaporization rate of carbon disulfide in case of a spill.  The total containment volume is 26,015 gallons.  The working volume of a railcar is 18,000 gal

lons.  This provides for 144 percent of the railcar volume.  The surface area of the containment is 966 square feet and the height is 3.5 feet.  The containment is flooded with enough water to keep a ?couple of inches? of water over the entire bottom of the containment.
The process at the Nylonge facility uses a highly refined wood pulp as raw material, which is showered with caustic (sodium hydroxide) and fed to the reactors.  There are temperature and pressure transmitters on the reactor to keep track of the conditions inside the reactor.  Sponge manufacturing is a batch process.  The reaction is monitored.  Water is added to the reactor to make a viscous cellulose (viscose).  Bacteria absorbing CS2 is used to make sulfur or sulfuric acid.  The biological system currently uses an inert media that will not deteriorate the sulfuric acid.  No catalyst is used in the reactor.  Instead, a combination of the organic and inert media is used.
Heating of the sponge with sulfuric acid causes the formation of toxic gases, which are removed by the scrubber.  There is also a secondary scrubber, which uses caustic and removes about 20% of the exhaust gases.  Sulfuric acid is further used in the wastewater process system.
Offsite Consequence Analysis Results
The offsite consequence analysis includes consideration of two carbon disulfide release scenarios, identified as "worst-case release scenario" and "alternative release scenario".  The first scenario is defined by EPA, which states that "the owner or operator shall assume that the ... maximum quantity in the largest vessel ... is released as a gas over 10-minutes," due to an unspecified failure.  The alternative scenario is defined as "more likely to occur than the worst case release scenario".
Atmospheric dispersion modeling has to be performed to determine the distance traveled by the carbon disulfide released before its concentration decreases to the "toxic endpoint" selected by EPA of 50 ppm, which is the Emergency Respon

se Planning Guideline Level 2 (ERPG-2).  This is defined by the American Industrial Hygiene Association (AIHA) as the "maximum airborne concentration below which it is believed that nearly all individuals could be exposed for up to one hour without experiencing or developing irreversible or other serious health effects or symptoms which could impair an individual?s ability to take protective action."  The residential population within a circle with a radius corresponding to the toxic endpoint distance has to be defined, "to estimate the population potentially affected".
The worst-case release scenario at the Nylonge Elyria Facility involves a failure of the railcar and a release of 189,300 pounds of carbon disulfide to the atmosphere over a 10-minute duration, regardless of how improbable this may be.  The released carbon disulfide would evaporate as it falls from the railcar into the dike provided around the railcar.  This dike is filled with water to reduce the evaporation of carbon disulfide after it spills into the dike.  The carbon disulfide evaporation is reduced because it is denser than water and it will settle at the bottom of the dike.  Therefore, the carbon disulfide release rate to the atmosphere was estimated to be about 14 lbs./min.
USEPA and Ohio EPA regulations require that the models used for dispersion analysis should appropriately account for the density of the released gas.  Since the carbon disulfide cloud formed during the worst-case release scenario would be denser-than-air, the USEPA guidance document was used for performing the consequence analysis.  The USEPA guidance document accounted for the dense gas behavior of carbon disulfide releases.
USEPA and Ohio EPA-mandated meteorological conditions, namely Stability F, wind speed of 1.5 m/sec, highest daily maximum temperature (104?F), and average humidity (50%) were used for the dispersion modeling analysis.  The results of the dispersion modeling analysis indicated that the worst-case scenar

io has offsite impacts.
The USEPA and Ohio EPA regulations require that a scenario, which is more likely to occur than the worst-case scenario should be selected as the alternative release scenario.  Unlike the worst-case scenario, the alternative release scenario may consider ?active? mitigation such as automatic shutoff valves and scrubbers.  Active mitigation is defined as requiring mechanical, electrical, or human input.  In addition, the selected scenario should reach the toxic endpoint offsite, unless no such scenario exists.
The alternative release scenarios must consider the facility accident history and/or failure scenarios identified in the hazard review.  A review of the past five-year accident history data for the carbon disulfide facility pursuant to these rules indicated that there was no carbon disulfide release, which resulted in offsite (outside the Elyria facility boundary) toxic endpoint distances.
The scenario selected for the Elyria carbon disulfide system involves the release of carbon disulfide as a result of a crack in the transfer pipeline from the railcar to the bulk storage tank.  It is assumed that all the liquid carbon disulfide present in the 135-foot pipeline will be released and will fall to the ground in an undiked area and then evaporate.  The total quantity of carbon disulfide released during the alternative release scenario was estimated at 232 lbs.  The carbon disulfide release rate from evaporation was estimated at 14.2 lbs./min.
The alternative release scenario toxic endpoint was also estimated using the USEPA guidance document.  The toxic endpoint for carbon disulfide is 50 ppm.  The results of the dispersion modeling analysis indicated that the alternative release scenario has offsite impacts.  The typical meteorological conditions used were Stability D, wind speed 3.0 m/s, average air temperature of 51?F, and 50% average humidity.
Finally, no carbon disulfide releases that could have caused safety or health hazard (deaths, i

njuries, property or environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place) occurred at the Nylonge Elyria Facility during the last five years.
Summary of the Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps
The Nylonge accidental release prevention program is based on the following key elements:
?    Detailed management system and clear levels of responsibilities and team member roles.
?    Comprehensive safety information that is readily available to staff, emergency responders, and contractors.
?    Comprehensive preventive maintenance program.
?    Performance of hazard review of equipment and procedures with operation and maintenance staff participation and review.
?    Use of state-of-the-art process and safety equipment.
?    Use of accurate and effective operating procedures, written with the participation of the operators.
?    High level of training of the operators and maintenance staff.
?    Implementation of an incident investigation, inspection, and auditing program using qualified staff.
Safety Information
Comprehensive chemical data has been assembled to include regulatory reporting and action thresholds, health hazard, and chemical exposure limitations, as well as detailed physical properties of carbon disulfide.  This information includes carbon disulfide background information and MSDS sheets.
Equipment safety information was compiled on the carbon disulfide process. Specifications for the carbon disulfide process are collected and provided in one place for easy reference. Details such as maximum intended inventory; safe upper and lower temperatures; and safe upper and lower pressures for the Nylonge facility are on file at the facility.  Nylonge also has procedures in place that are triggered to update safety information if there is a major change that makes existing information inaccurate.
Hazard Review 
As part of an update of the Risk Management Program/Plan (RMP), a hazard review was performed on July 9, 2001 for the carbon disulfide

system.  The hazard review was performed using the Hazard and Operability (HAZOP) technique.  The hazard review included an orientation session, where the participants were informed of the relevant materials and processes involved; RMP requirements; and the hazard evaluation technique to be followed.  The hazard review team members received training prior to the start and during the performance of the analysis.  The hazard review covered both equipment and main procedures used for the carbon disulfide system.  It will be updated again within a five-year period or prior to a major change in the process.  A list of recommended actions has been developed based on the July 2001 hazard review and staff is currently evaluating these recommendations.  Staff will document the completion of these recommended actions.
Operating Procedures
Nylonge Corporation has prepared written operating procedures for the Elyria facility that provides clear instructions or steps for safely conducting activities relating to the carbon disulfide system.  These instructions or steps include the following:
?    Railcar to storage tank transfer
?    Storage tank to batch tank transfer
?    Start
?    Normal Operations
?    Shutdown, and
?    Operating Problems and Remedies.
The Nylonge Corporation has also developed operator checklists for transferring carbon disulfide from railcar to the bulk storage tank and from bulk storage tanks to reactor tanks.  Preventive maintenance is performed prior to each carbon disulfide transfer as determined by the operators? assessment of the equipment, proper engineering practices and prior operating experience.  The operator, prior to each transfer, also completes the carbon disulfide handling system inspection/maintenance log.
Training 
    Nylonge Corporation ensures that each employee operating or maintaining the carbon disulfide system, and each employee newly assigned to this system, is trained and tested for competency in the operating procedures listed above listed above.

The Nylonge employee training documentation files include training records for each employee assigned to operate or maintain the carbon disulfide system.  The training ensures that the employee has the required knowledge, skills, and abilities to safely carry out the duties and responsibilities, including carbon disulfide emergency response, as provided in the operating procedures.  Employee training includes as a minimum the following elements:
?    Safety Information.
?    Process Technology and Process Equipment, including safety systems.
?    Maintenance Procedures.
?    Operating Procedures for the carbon disulfide system.
?    RMP Program contents.
?    Emergency Response Plan and Procedures.
    Refresher training is provided at least every three years to each employee operating the carbon disulfide system to ensure that the employee understands and adheres to the current operating procedures.  In addition, Nylonge ensures that operators are trained in any updated or new procedures prior to startup of a process after major modifications.
Maintenance 
Nylonge operates a program that generates a task order for performance of the preventive maintenance routine after a designated time past the closing of the previous task order for that maintenance.  Description of the work to be performed is included with the printed work order.
    Nylonge documents inspection, testing, and maintenance of carbon disulfide system equipment and assures the performance is done in accordance with the recommendations of the manufacturer and industry groups.
Internal Compliance Audits
    Nylonge Corporation will certify every three years (or earlier) that compliance with Program 2 Prevention Program requirements are met and that procedures and practices developed are adequate and being followed.
The compliance audit will consist of separating the RMP program elements or sections, and auditing each element to determine compliance and effectiveness.  For each internal audit, the audit team will complete a Compl

iance Audit Certification Page and a Compliance Audit Checklist.  The Compliance Audit Certification Page provides process identification, the dates of the audit, team members, and certification by the audit leader and the Plant Manager.  The Compliance Audit Checklist details the requirements of each RMP element and contains questions that may assist with the auditing process.  The audit checklist for each element consists of the following three sections:
?    Records Review: A review of the RMP written Prevention Program.
?    On-Site Conditions: The audit team will review the program elements based on observation of the plant conditions and safety practices.
?    Interviews:  The program elements will be evaluated by interviewing personnel from appropriate functions including operations, maintenance, management, and contractors.
Team members will record RMP program deficiencies identified during the audit on the checklist. 
Incident Investigation
Nylonge has developed incident investigation procedures, which requires the analysis of each accident and reporting to various regulatory agencies.  The incident investigation shall be started promptly but no later than 48 hours after the event.  Nylonge will promptly address and resolve all recommendations and shall implement the recommendations in a timely manner to prevent an incident recurrence.  All incident investigation reports will be retained on Nylonge file for at least a period of five years from the date the reports are completed.  The report, at a minimum, will include: 
?    Date of incident.
?    Date investigation began.
?    A description of the incident.
?    Factors contributed to the incident.
?    Recommendations resulting from the investigation.
Five-year Accident History Summary
The USEPA and Ohio EPA regulations require the details of the five-year accident history of the covered processes.  However, the details of accidental releases are required only for those accidents, which must have caused at least one of the follo

wing:
?    On-site deaths, injuries, or significant property damage; or
?    Known offsite deaths, injuries, property damage, environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place.
No accidental releases involving carbon disulfide have occurred at the Elyria facility during the last five years, which would fall under these two categories.
Emergency Response Program Summary
The Nylonge facility emergency response policy involves the preparation of a response plan, which is tailored to the facility and to the emergency response services available in the community; and is in compliance with the USEPA and Ohio EPA Emergency Response Requirements.
Elyria facility is a first responder, its trained employees respond to carbon disulfide accidental releases.
As part of the emergency response program, the Elyria facility has developed and implemented an emergency action plan (Standard 1400-3) for the purpose of protecting public health and the environment.
Planned Changes to Improve Safety
As part of an update of the Risk Management Program/Plan (RMP), a hazard review was performed on July 9, 2001 for the carbon disulfide system.  The hazard review was performed using the Hazard and Operability (HAZOP) technique.  The hazard review included an orientation session, where the participants were informed of the relevant materials and processes involved; RMP requirements; and the hazard evaluation technique to be followed.  The hazard review team members received training prior to the start and during the performance of the analysis.  The hazard review covered both equipment and main procedures used for the carbon disulfide system.  A list of recommended actions has been developed based on the July 2001 hazard review and staff is currently evaluating these recommendations.  The implementation of these recommendations will further improve the safety of the carbon disulfide system.
